message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is referring to MHC class I molecules, which present antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes. MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin, making option (B) the correct answer. Option (A) is referring to MHC class II molecules, which present antigens to CD4+ T-lymphocytes. Option (C) is incorrect as MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy and a light chain, not two chains of equal length. Option (D) is incorrect as MHC class I molecules can be expressed by all nucleated cells, not just antigen-presenting cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question describes a viral infection, and in viral infections, infected cells present viral antigens on MHC class I molecules. MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. Therefore, option B is the most accurate statement. Option A is incorrect since antigens are loaded onto MHC class I molecules in the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes. Option C is incorrect since MHC class I molecules consist of one heavy chain and β2 microglobulin. Option D is incorrect since MHC class I molecules are expressed by all nucleated cells, not just antigen-presenting cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking about the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules involved in antigen presentation to CD8+ T-lymphocytes. Option B correctly describes MHC class I molecules, which consist of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. Antigens are loaded onto these molecules within the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes. MHC class II molecules, not MHC class I, are made up of 2 chains of equal length and are selectively expressed by antigen-presenting cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the molecule suggests it is MHC class I, which consists of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. Option (A) is not accurate as the antigens are loaded onto the molecule within the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes. Option (C) is not accurate as MHC class I consists of one long and one short chain. Option (D) is not accurate as MHC class I is expressed by all nucleated cells, not just antigen-presenting cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question refers to MHC class I molecules, which present antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes. MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. They are found on almost all nucleated cells and are not selectively expressed by antigen-presenting cells. The antigens are loaded onto the molecule in the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes. The molecule is made up of two chains of unequal length, with the alpha chain being longer than the beta-2 microglobulin chain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking about MHC class I molecules, which are responsible for presenting antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes. MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy chain and β2 microglobulin. Option A is incorrect as the antigens are loaded onto the molecule within the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes. Option C is incorrect as MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy chain and a shorter chain, not 2 chains of equal length. Option D is incorrect as MHC class I molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells, not just antigen-presenting cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is describing the MHC class I molecule, which consists of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. MHC class I molecules present antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes, and their antigen-loading occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes. The molecule is also not selectively expressed by antigen-presenting cells, as all nucleated cells express MHC class I molecules. The description of the molecule as consisting of 2 chains of equal length is more characteristic of MHC class II molecules, which present antigens to CD4+ T-lymphocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the molecule used for antigen presentation matches with the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecule, which consists of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. Option A describes MHC class II molecule, which presents antigens from extracellular pathogens. Option C describes T-cell receptor, which recognizes antigens presented by MHC molecules. Option D is not specific enough and is misleading as MHC class I molecules are expressed by almost all nucleated cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The molecule used for presentation of antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes is the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I. It consists of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin, making option (B) the correct answer. Option (A) is incorrect because antigens are loaded onto MHC class II molecules within lysosomes. Option (C) is incorrect because MHC class I molecules consist of a heavy chain and a light chain, not two chains of equal length. Option (D) is incorrect because MHC class I molecules are expressed by all nucleated cells, not just antigen-presenting cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is referring to the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) I molecule used for presenting antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes. Option (B) is correct as it accurately describes the structure of MHC I, which consists of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin. The antigens are loaded onto the molecule in the endoplasmic reticulum, not lysosomes, making option (A) incorrect. MHC I is made up of one heavy chain and one short peptide chain, not two chains of equal length, making option (C) incorrect. Finally, while antigen-presenting cells do express MHC I, it is not selectively expressed by them, making option (D) incorrect.
